channel.title: Dots at the end of an int?

item.title: Dots at the end of an int?
item.dc:creator: @repacsenur repacsenur
item.description:
@repacsenur wrote:

once you convert a double to a int it will always be a int if it’s datatype is a int so its pretty pointless to make a constant double to be casted as a int because it will still be a int… better just round it and save it as a int.

Read full topic
item.source: Dots at the end of an int?

item.title: Dots at the end of an int?
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“Adam, post:4, topic:336711”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=433121.msg3179439#msg3179439 date=1271187746]
ohh i see, the guy who wrote it was probably an idiot then because none of the vars are doubles.
[/quote]
/facepalm

There are circumstances where you want a variable to be a different type… Sometime’s it’s useful to cast a double as an integer and vice versa.[/quote]Wow, epic fail.

P.S. decimals are also used in floats

item.title: Dots at the end of an int?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

A dot means the number will be treated as a double (as opposed to an int, which is the usual case). However, it is pointless since the double is converted back to an int in each such assignments. Actually, in Java, an int cast is required so that src is probably bs.

One reason you would use a dot is fractions:
double d = 5.0/9.0; (5/9 would yield 0 because int division truncates)

By the way, don’t ever use a dot by itself like that. “3.0” is much more legible than “3.”, yet yields the same value and properties.

Read full topic
item.source: Dots at the end of an int?

item.title: Dots at the end of an int?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

i’m reading the source to a java applet that does loads of maths stuff, and all the int assignments have dots after the value. eg,
int bacon;
bacon = 100.;

what does it mean?

Read full topic
item.source: Dots at the end of an int?
